Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Outerwall-selectively Functionalized Double-Wall Carbon Nanotubes--Optical and Electrical Properties of Semiconducting Nanotubes in a Multifunctional Carbon Shell
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry (MSN) program of the Division of Chemistry will support the CAREER research and education program of Prof. YuHuang Wang of University of Maryland College Park. Prof. Wang and his students will develop new functionalization chemistry for double-wall carbon nanotubes, which will retain the remarkable optical and electronic properties of pristine single-walled carbon nanotubes. This outerwall concept represents a significant departure from current approaches that utilize single wall carbon nanotubes and focus on protecting their properties through delicate surface modifications. Prof. Wang and his students will measure the optical and electrical transport properties of the inner tube of double wall carbon nanotubes and benchmark them against those of pristine single-walled nanotubes, double-wall nanotubes and functionalized single-walled nanotubes. These efforts will shed new light on carbon nanomaterials chemistry and afford researchers new chemical and nanometrology tools to reveal and control how local chemical environments mediate the electronic properties of nanostructures.

Successful completion of the proposed study will enable the use of double-wall carbon nanotubes in a wide range of applications for example as coatings in electronic devices and solar cells and as biomedical imaging probes and drug delivery carriers. The CAREER educational plans of Prof. Wang involve the development of an innovative curriculum in nanomaterials and outreach activities for high school students including students from under-represented groups in the area of nanoscience and nanotechnology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This CAREER award from the chemistry division of NSF has had a very positive impact on the career development of both the PI and students in his research group. The potential impact is far reaching, in both areas of intellectual merit and broader impacts.

Intellectual Merit. With the support of this award, the PI and his research group at the University of Maryland have published 17 manuscripts, including 2 under review, in journals with very high impact for the field, including Nature Chemistry,1 Nature Communications,2 Journal of the American Chemical Society,3, 4 ACS Nano,5 and several others.6-15 The outcomes also include 1 invited book chapter16 and 2 patent applications. As proposed, the team has successfully created a unique synthetic semiconductor, termed tube-in-a-tube (Tube^2), that is equivalent to a SWCNT nested in a chemically tailored, atomically-thick carbon shell. This structure is created by outer wall-selective functionalization of double-walled carbon nanotubes. A double-walled nanotube consists of exactly two SWCNTs, one nested within another. The team discovered that covalent modification turns the outer wall into an insulator, decouples inter-wall interactions, and allows the surface to be chemically tailored to afford surface functionality and solubility inherently lacking in SWCNTs and graphene.4, 6, 10 All the while, the inner tube retains the remarkable electrical and optical properties of SWCNTs. Tube^2 thus provides a unique combination of solubility and exceptional properties required for many applications. For example, by combining the protected electrical properties of the inner tube with robust outer wall chemistry, Tube^2 opens exciting new opportunities for device innovation and experimental probing of electronic nanostructures in a chemically-tailored atom-thick shell. A thin-film transistor sensor is demonstrated to address the challenge of simultaneously attaining ultrahigh sensitivity and selectivity in the electrical detection of small molecules.4 The intact semiconducting inner tube provides an NH3 sensitivity of 60 nM (or ~1 ppb). Moreover, the carboxylic acid-functionalized outer wall makes it possible to simultaneously attain 6,000 times higher chemical selectivity towards amine-containing analytes over other small molecules.

Broader Impacts. The proposed activities have led to the development of an innovative electronic sensors based on Tube^2. A proposal has been submitted to NIH and subsequently funded through an R01 award to explore potential further applications of Tube^2 in the area of biomedicine. The findings have been widely disseminated through invited talks by PI (42) and presentations/posters by graduate students (28, including 15 at national and international meetings). Primarily based on this work, three graduate students have received their PhD degrees, seven graduate students and three undergraduate researchers collectively won 16 prestigious awards/fellowships and 4 travel grants. Furthermore, the CAREER research involves 2 high school students and 2 high school teachers. Through collaboration with the high school teachers, three NanoLab demos are developed to illustrate some of the basic concepts of nanoscience based on ongoing research in PI’s lab. The demos have been partially integrated in their lesson plans. Part of the resulting research has also been covered in the science and technology press, including Nature Chemistry17 and the YouTube Channel of the American Chemical Society as part of the celebration of the National Chemistry Week.18, 19 The video clips have collectively received more than 37,500 views on YouTube, with many positive notes from the general public.
